awd_titl_txt: RUI: Biochemical Analysis of Mastermind Dependent Activation of Notch Target Genes
awd_abstract_narration:
Intellectual Merit.  Notch signaling is an important and highly significant topic to understand because it represents one of the five major signal transduction pathways (Wnt/beta-catenin, Hedgehog, receptor tyrosine kinases, nuclear receptors, and Notch) found in all metazoan organisms responsible for growth, differentiation, and maintenance of cells. Misregulation of Notch signaling can result in developmental as well as disease states. After ligand activation of the Notch receptor, an intracellular segment (NICD) translocates to the nucleus. The NICD forms a ternary complex with the Mam (Mastermind) protein and other proteins to activate target genes. In humans, there are three Mam proteins (Mam1-3). Each Mam contains an amino terminal basic domain that interacts with NICD and a carboxy terminal acidic region that likely functions in transcriptional activation. Truncated versions of Mam1 that lose these carboxyl regions, but retain the basic domain, produce dominant negative phenotypes when they are over-expressed in model organisms. The overall goal of this project is to dissect the molecular elements of the Mam family of proteins that are necessary for Notch signaling with the goal of gaining insight into the complexity at the molecular level. Yeast two-hybrid screens and biochemical protein-protein pull down techniques will be employed to identify Mam-interacting partners from tissue culture cell lines. The role of putative Mam-interacting proteins will be determined though a combination of molecular and biochemical approaches.

Broader Impacts. This project will benefit undergraduate students who will receive training in biochemistry and molecular biology at San José State University (SJSU). The majority of students attending SJSU are from economically disadvantaged families. A number of these students are from underrepresented or first time college attendees. This project will provide students with a unique opportunity to learn and conduct research. Students will be encouraged to think and design their own experiments and will present their results at both state and national conferences. Further, to reach as many students as possible, some of the research methods developed during this project will also be incorporated into an undergraduate molecular biology laboratory course.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: SAN JOSE STATE UNIVERSITY RESEARCH FOUNDATION

por.por_cntn:
Scientific Outcomes

The project investigated the role that a protein called mastermind plays in regulation of gene expression. Mastermind is protein found in all multi-cellular organisms in the animal kingdom. Originally, this protein was identified to function with another protein, Notch, to activate specific genes that have been shown to be important in developmental processes such as muscle differentation,nueron differentiation, and blood cell development. Mis-activation of Notch has been shown to be involved in the formation of certain cancers. Most studies have focused on the importance of notch. More recently, mastermind has been show to also function in other transcriptional networks that contribute muscle differentiation (MEF2C) and control cell death (p53) suggesting that mis-regulation of mastermind may also play important roles in disease pathogenesis. Therefore, a fundamental question is understanding how mastermind works in transcriptional networks. We published a paper from this grant which showed that mastermind is an unstable protein in the cell in the absence notch.  The stability of mastermind was controlled through ubiquitiation, a mechanism by which the cell destroys proteins it does not need.  In the presence of notch, mastermind was not ubiquitinated. We further identified the amino acids for the ubiquitination and whe they were changed, the protein was more stable and increased transcription of notch target genes in the presence of notch. Our data suggests that mastermind must remain at low levels in the cell when not required or could lead to aberrant transcription. We are also in the process of publishing two more papers from this work. One paper shows that mastermind is able to induce rapid degradation of MEF2C when expressed together. A final paper is characterizing the DNA binding sites required for Notch and mastermind to function together to activate target genes.

Broader Impact Outcomes

This project inroduced seven undergraduate students and two masters students to research in a laboratory and helped those students develope the necessary skills to make them succesful in the scientific community after graduating. Four of those students went on to purse advanced degress (MPH, PhD and DO) and the other five students went on to jobs in the biotechnology community. Further, a post-doctoral fellow was hired on this grant and received training and mentoring in both research and teaching.

In addition to training and mentoring students in the research lab, a molecular biology laboratory course was developed and funded from this grant. This course is now offered every year to 36-54 undergraduate students. The course is self-sustaining and now fully funded in the department and will remain so in the long-term future.

Impacts on Society

The teachingand  mentoring supported by this project has allowed students and postdocs to better appreciate the values of hard work, team work and collaborative efforts, time management, ethical conduct, professionalism and appropriate behavior in a ethnically diverse environment. The project also helped the economy in San Jose by employing personnel and by purchasing research materials and services.


Last Modified: 08/04/2015
Modified by: Brandon White
